body:
Hi @akwon31 

Wondering if you have made any headway in adding estimates of transaction costs to the online strategies? If so, how are you counting the transactions? 

Are you using changes in portfolio allocations to specific stocks to estimate transactions? If not, which approach are you using?

@cschiri I think it will be a while until I start on the transaction costs. I'd assume that I'll calculate it by tracking the change in the number of assets and using bps to adjust the portfolio returns.

Hi @akwon31 

On Estimating Transaction Costs for Online Strategies

I came up with a simple and crude Pandas-based methodology for computing online strategy transaction costs.

It uses three inputs:
1) Transaction Costs.
2) Weights of Portfolio Elements.
3) Cumulative Returns of the Portfolio.

See below:

```
# Get Weights and Returns from All Tickers

weights = strategy.all_weights
returns = strategy.portfolio_return
returns.columns = ["cummulative_strategy_returns"]


# Helper Function for Estimating Transaction Costs from Rebalancing Portfolio

def compute_net_cummulative_returns(returns, weights, transaction_costs=0.005):
    
    print("Total Weighting Changes Per Ticker:")
    print("")
    print((weights != weights.shift(axis=0)).sum(axis=0))
    daily_transaction_frame = ((weights != weights.shift(axis=0)).cumsum(axis=0)).diff()
    daily_transaction_frame = daily_transaction_frame.fillna(value=1)
    
    gross_allocation = weights.mul(returns['cummulative_strategy_returns'], axis=0)
    net_allocation_absolute = np.abs(gross_allocation.diff())
    transaction_costs_per_ticker = net_allocation_absolute.mul(transaction_costs)
    transactions_costs_aggregate = pd.DataFrame(transaction_costs_per_ticker.sum(axis=1), columns=["aggregrate_costs"])
    transactions_costs_aggregate = transactions_costs_aggregate.fillna(value=0)
    transactions_costs_aggregate.iloc[0, transactions_costs_aggregate.columns.get_loc('aggregrate_costs')] = transaction_costs
    profitability_elements = pd.concat([returns, transactions_costs_aggregate], axis=1)
    net_cummulative_returns = pd.DataFrame((profitability_elements["cummulative_strategy_returns"] - \
                                            profitability_elements["aggregrate_costs"]), 
                                            columns=["net_cummulative_returns"])

    return daily_transaction_frame, net_cummulative_returns

daily_transaction_frame, net_cummulative_returns = compute_net_cummulative_returns(returns, weights, transaction_costs=0.005)
net_cummulative_returns
```

Is the method in harmony with the other computations that are made by the sub-module? I just want to be sure that it is a
logically and mathematically sound approach.

Best
-C.
@Jackal08 any reasons for keeping this one open?
Hi @aditya1702, this is a list of algorithms that we can still implement in the OLPS module. So a type of ice bucket ticket.

About Short Selling
I dont think its very necessary to add short selling as part of the package. If I need to short sell, just put asset A (which is long ) and (-1)*A (which is short ) together, and then calculate the net weight of asset A in the portfolio.  Since it nets off some weight in asset A, it will leave some cash on hand, the sum of weight of each asset is not 100%.
Suggest PPN model in [Cost-Sensitive Portfolio Selection via Deep Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2003.03051)
hi, @aditya1702 @Jackal08 I would like to contribute to the list of algorithms that we can implement in the OLPS module in this project. Can I?
